dynamic-content.content: The Canoe Festival - International Descent of the Sella River
First Saturday in August (unless it's the 1st or 2nd day)
The Canoe Festival of Asturias, steeped in tradition

Also known as the International Descent of the Sella River, it is one of the most popular festivals both within and outside of Asturias. Combining the playful and sporting aspects, the Canoe Festival seamlessly blends the charm and excitement of a canoe race on calm waters with a distinctly Asturian celebration, all in a truly privileged setting along the waters and banks of the Sella River, as the sporting competition takes place between Arriondas/Les Arriondes and Ribadesella/Ribeseya, in the easternmost part of Asturias.

This canoe race is one of the oldest in the world and marks the birth of competitive canoeing in calm waters in Spain. Therefore, it is a major sporting event that incorporates all the "rituals" of a typical Asturian festival: music, parade of brass bands, cider, and the playing of the "Asturias Patria Querida" anthem, signaling the start of the race, just a few kilometers away from the impressive peaks of the Picos de Europa.

The Canoe Festival, there is no merrier celebration, no more Asturian essence.

Festival of Tourist Interest in the Principality of Asturias
La Regalina in Cadavéu, Father Galo's dream with views of the sea

There are few festivals in Asturias that have been founded and promoted by an intellectual and humanist of the stature of Father Galo. Born in Cadavéu, this priest with cosmopolitan experiences, wide cultural horizons, polyglot, and writer in the Asturian language, founded this festival in 1931, and since then it has been held on the last Sunday in August.

Another of the singularities of La Regalina is that it takes place in the open air in the field of La Garita, next to the Hermitage of Santa María de Riégala, from where there are unique views of the coast and its spectacular cliffs.

The Regalina is one of the unmissable summer events in the council of Valdés, and due to its origins and peculiarities it is a very heartfelt festival, which arouses unwavering support and deep admiration in all those who know it.
Asturcón Festival or the celebration of an indigenous breed

The Asturcón is the quintessential Asturian horse. For decades, it has been bred and raised freely in the Sueve Mountains, simultaneously warding off the threat of extinction. That's why, for over 35 years, a festival has been held in its honor: to acquaint the public with it and to showcase its fantastic recovery thanks to the dedication of local breeders.

The setting for the Asturcón Festival is also an idyllic mountain landscape known as Majada de Espineres. There, an unforgettable day takes place in the heart of nature, featuring a little bit of everything: open-air mass, awards ceremony, branding and taming show, countryside feast, and lots of traditional Asturian music and festivities.
Festival of Tourist Interest of the Principality of Asturias
The perfect complement to El Carmen

The Feast of Santa María Magdalena cannot be conceived without the Feast of El Carmen, nor the latter without the former. In reality, the festivities of Magdalena are an extension of the first, and it is precisely this new festive episode that causes the people of Cangas to spend almost the entire month of July living for the devotions and processions of their virgins.

The main day of this festival coincides six days after the Feast of El Carmen.

On that day, there is a procession, a mass in the basilica, a fireworks display in honor of the virgin, and of course, there is no shortage of outings and lively open-air dances.

With these festivities, the final touch is put on several weeks of uninterrupted celebration and animation in the town of Cangas, which is overflowing with tourists, locals, and Cangas natives who are away from their land and return each year eager for family reunions, fireworks, and devotion. And, of course, all these festivities involve numerous recreational and cultural events that take place throughout the month of July.
Festival of Touristic Interest of the Principality of Asturias

The main day is July 22nd, the feast day of Santa María Magdalena. In Llanes, this day is announced by fireworks at eight in the morning. Later, a parade, made up of members and supporters of the band, roams through the town to the rhythm of the pasodoble "El Magdaleno," performed by the music band, concluding at La Magdalena square. From there, the procession of the Saint begins towards the Basilica, where the Solemn Mass takes place.

After the Holy Mass, the procession takes place, passing through the so-called "Barrio de la Magdalena" (Magdalena neighborhood). Once the Saint is placed in her chapel, the grand Folk Festival begins, performed by members of the band. It includes original compositions, in addition to the genuine Pericote llanisco. Upon conclusion, the Dance of San Joaquín (a variety of Danza Prima) is performed, continuing until the chapel, where the morning events conclude.

After lunch, a concert is offered by the music band, performing classical pieces along with exclusive compositions from the band. Then, the pilgrimage begins until dusk, when the Dance of San Joaquín resumes until the chapel. At night, a grand open-air dance concludes the festivities.
Nava's Natural Cider Festival, as authentic as it gets

This is the most veteran cider festival held in Asturias, dating back to the 60s of the 20th century. What started as a tribute to the Asturian drink par excellence has consolidated itself as a fiesta attended by thousands of people every year and held right in the middle of the summer.

This festival, with its cider and cider pouring contest, includes many activities linked to the world of apples and cider, while also the Asturian culture and traditions, renewing its programme every year.

The place where it is held, Nava, is one of the Asturian cider production capitals, where cider makers and brewers, with both classic and totally modern premises, meet. Furthermore, this village of the Cider Region is well known both in and outside Asturias as it is the home of the Cider Museum where, in an entertaining and interactive manner, one can learn about the world and the culture of cider, from its beginnings to the present.
Festival of Touristic Interest of the Principality of Asturias

For several decades, the Natural Cider Festival of Gijón brightens up the last week of August and therefore the end of the summer. Undoubtedly the festival is one of the grand, classical venues of the summer in Gijón and has an extensive programme of activities.

Urban art, ephemeral art, the little cider and apple market, courses on cider pouring, the cider bus, the visits to emblematic cider cellars, the cider pouring competition, theatre, the cancios de chigre (traditional songs), food tasting and the presentation of prizes are some of the typical activities of a festival which floods streets and squares with a special atmosphere, and permeates the city with the air of cider.

Especially outstanding is the world record of simultaneous pouring which is beaten each year on the famous Poniente Beach, and which adds a touch of colour and originality which is unique in the world.
Festival of touristic interest in the Principality of Asturias

Holy Week in Avilés is of vital importance. The quintessential medieval city of Asturias passionately celebrates Holy Week, a tradition that dates back to the distant 17th century, although the form it has taken in modern times emerged in the first half of the 20th century.

The setting of the historic city center is unparalleled for the staging of the rituals and processions of Holy Week. The passage of the religious floats through the old streets lined with arcades, squares, churches, palaces, and other well-preserved noble buildings, representing architectural styles ranging from the 12th century to the present day, transforms the city into a perfect stage of culture, history, and devotion.

Thousands of members of different brotherhoods take to the streets, each with their own guild, and dozens of floats, processions, and images flood the ancestral and historical Avilés. The entire city vibrates upon its stones, which exude a passionate past and present.

And as the culmination of so much emotion, the end of the procession calendar gives way to the Fiesta del Bollo, declared a National Tourist Interest event, which takes place on Easter Monday. Undoubtedly, the perfect finale for a unique Holy Week in Asturias and in Spain.
Tourist Interest Festival of the Principality of Asturias
Holy Week in Villaviciosa, a very ancient passion

The Holy Week of Villaviciosa is one of the oldest in Asturias. Its celebration is already documented in the 17th century, and the truth is that the people of Maliayés have been passing down the tradition and spirit of Holy Week from generation to generation, commemorating each year a religious festival that also has a strong cultural and artistic component.

The entire town comes together to commemorate the Mysteries of the Passion and Death of Jesus of Nazareth, gladly expressing a tradition and sentiment inherited from their ancestors in a public manner.

The religious images displayed during the Holy Week of Villaviciosa hold high artistic value, and the celebrations, especially on Wednesday and Good Friday, are truly worth it because during those days one can witness the Encounter and the Descent from the Cross or Unnailing, which are true sacramental acts with great dramatic force.

Holy Week is lived with passion in the streets of Villaviciosa, and everything is filled with devotion, representation, and tradition. It is a magnificent opportunity to get to know this town with so much history, a vibrant atmosphere, and hospitable and open-hearted people.
Festival of touristic interest in Asturias
From the 'Jueves de Comadres' (Mates' Thursday) to the Carnival Tuesday

Carnival is popular fiesta time in Asturias. It is true that all the region returns for the ritual of Carnival: disguises, charanga groups, parades, frixuelos (crepes) (a sweet typical of the Carnival time), music, fun, packed streets and squares, in villages and cities. It is also true that, if Antroxu or Carnival is especially relevant and outstanding in a place in Asturias, that place is Avilés.

In the days of Antroxu, this city with its fishing, seagoing and port tradition becomes a grand open air scenario where light, colour, disguises, of which there are thousands, and the festival in abundance fills the streets and squares of the city.  The Antroxu of Avilés has deserved fame, especially its well-known Descenso de Galiana (Descent of Galiana Street), which is one of the culminating moments of this celebration, highlighting all the beauty and tradition of the historical quarter of Avilés.

For these and many other reasons, the Antroxu of Avilés is mythical, and must be lived. It is very recommendable that you join in the atmosphere, disguise yourself and join a group as this is much more fun.

Of course, it is one of the most outstanding Festivals of Touristic Interest in the festive calendar.
Fiestas of touristic interest in the Principality of Asturias
From the 'Jueves de Comadres' (Mates' Thursday) to the Carnival Tuesday
Or the city which disguises itself

The people of Gijón are by nature Antroxu people and they go all out to celebrate their Carnival. In this city the Carnival is a type of religion, and the ritual is socially so essential that the citizens of Gijón/Xixón cannot be separated from this grand festive venue.

The participation is massive and the main streets of Gijón/Xixón, taking the central Paseo de Begoña with its emblematic Teatro Jovellanos, as well as the District of the Fishermen, the Marina, the Wall of San Lorenzo and other zones as the neurological centre, this is literally flooded by the "fury" of Carnival which reaches its zenith in the grand parade of Monday and the fiesta finishes off with the Burial of the Sardine.

Clearly Gijón/Xixón is by nature passionate and Antroxu is just right for it. So much so that it releases the same passion as King Pelayo, whose statue stands majestically over the Plaza del Marqués peering at the sea horizon, and it becomes enraptured by the magic and fantasy of the Carnival.

The dates of the Carnival or Antroxu vary each year depending on the Christian calendar.
The Swimming Descent of the Ría de Navia
The Swimming Descent of the Ría de Navia, with sports as its emblem

This fiesta combines sport, culture and tradition. The Swimming Descent of the Ría de Navia is one of the best known and valued swimming races in in the European continent, with international swimmers and thousands of spectators thrilled by this sport attending it in the privileged setting of the Ría de Navia. This competition is a true classic that has been held in the Asturian town of Navia since the end of the 50s of the 20th century.

There has been a great sports tradition linked to swimming in the area of Navia since the beginnings of the 20th century, reaching its peak with the onset and development of this great race, while accompanied by many cultural and festive acts related to the traditions of western Asturias.

Asturian summer reaches one of its culminating moments with this fiesta, stating the taste for sports, culture and the fiesta in the Ría de Navia setting, in whose surroundings there has been great activity regarding commerce, fishing, etc. since long ago, leading to the resulting settlements.
The Swimming Descent of the Ría de Navia
ourist Interest Festival of the Principality of Asturias
The main activity of this festival consists of an outdoor sports march. At the same time, there are screenings and a photography contest, as well as musical performances and dancing celebrations

In its second edition, this popular march acquired international status, and from the third edition onwards, it became the perfect occasion for exploring the many tourism and leisure options offered by the municipality of Navia. Additionally, due to its massive attendance, it entered the Guinness Book of World Records, where its remarkable participation and uniqueness were acknowledged.

The International Journey of the Navia Coast takes place in remarkably beautiful landscapes, including beaches such as Barayo and Frexulfe, and fishing villages like Puerto de Vega. With an average participation of 2,000 people - reaching up to 4,000 registered participants in some years - it attracts thousands of people annually from within and outside of Asturias.

Furthermore, the attractive route of the march makes this event a benchmark in the field of hiking. So much so that many groups from other regions such as Galicia, León, Cantabria, or Madrid happily join this Journey, which also captures the attention of participants from other countries such as Argentina, Mexico, or Portugal.

The International Journey of the Navia Coast is usually celebrated on the second or third Sunday of June.

This unique festival is centered around a product closely tied to the fishing culture of Asturias, specifically from the area near the mouth of the Nalón River, where exceptionally high-quality baby eels, known as "angulas" in Spanish, have been found for generations

This gastronomic festival is the only one in Asturias dedicated exclusively to baby eels. It takes place during the first weekend of March, lasting three days, and has been celebrated for over thirty years.

This unique festival revolves around a product deeply connected to the fishing culture of Asturias, specifically from the area near the mouth of the Nalón River, where exceptional quality baby eels, known as "angulas" in Spanish, have always been found.

Moreover, in the fishing ports overlooking the sea in this part of Asturias, there is a strong culinary culture centered around various seafood dishes, but with a particular emphasis on expertise in preparing baby eels.

The festival has a strong popular following and a vibrant atmosphere, as visitors come from all parts of Asturias and beyond. If you wish to have an unforgettable gastronomic experience, don't miss out on this festival.
Hake with baby eels and prawns
Rally "Princess of Asturias", a luxury itinerary

The Rally "Princess of Asturias," which has been held for over 50 years and is one of Spain's oldest competitions, takes place in the first half of September.

The Rally attracts thousands of people who follow the different stages through various municipalities in Asturias.

If you enjoy motorsport and want to experience it in incomparable routes and natural settings, the Rally Princess of Asturias is an event you can't miss.

In addition to the appeal of the competition itself, you'll also enjoy the atmosphere, landscapes, quality gastronomy, and the endless personal discoveries you'll make by following the Rally itinerary, which presents new features in each edition.
National Tourist Interest Festival of the Principality of Asturias
Our Lady of the Rosary in Luarca/Ḷḷuarca, a perfect example of a maritime virgin in western Asturias

The Grand Day of this festival is the ultimate festive day in the Asturian summer: August 15th. The Virgin of the Rosary embodies the maritime virgin, and this is evident in the procession where her image sails on a decorated boat, accompanied by other equally adorned boats. The procession, which begins with a rocket salute, becomes a tribute that combines devotion to the virgin with the remembrance of fishermen who lost their lives at sea. All the boats sound their sirens and toss bouquets and wreaths of flowers into the Cantabrian Sea as a heartfelt and emotional homage to the absent ones.

The festive days are completed with a multitude of recreational, sports, cultural, and traditional activities related to the sea, music and dance, and culture, designed for children and adults. Luarca/Ḷḷuarca, the capital of the Valdés municipality, becomes during those days an authentic and warm festive destination on the western coast of Asturias.
Fiesta of touristic interest in the Principality of Asturias
When the river puts on its best finery

The Folkloric Descent of the Nalón is a humoristic water parade held on the River Nalón as it passes the district of Laviana. This is a fun festival in which the people and the people and the groups descend the river with different kinds of boats  built by themselves, each referring to different burning issues of the day.

The parade begins when the people go towards the Puente de Arco (Puente d'Arcu), where the popular song Chalaneru is sung, as a hymn. Once this is sung, the descent of the river begins in order to reach the Bridge of La Chalana, one and a half kilometres farther down. In the course of the river, the participants get round all kinds of difficulties with imagination, good humour and teamwork until the finish line established is reached, where thousands of people have gathered and there is a strong festive atmosphere.

It take place in August – usually in the second fortnight – coinciding with the celebration of the fiestas of the patroness the Virgen de Otero, in the capital of the district, La Pola Llaviana/ ola de Laviana. It is an authentic summer river carnival with lots of sensations and colour.
Festival of Touristic Interest of the Principality of Asturias
Living Stations of the Cross in Villanueva de Oscos, when Holy Week comes to life

During Holy Week, the town of Vilanova showcases a remarkable display of imagination and devotion, staging a popular theatrical reenactment of the Passion according to Saint Mark, with the participation of all the residents of this beautiful locality on Maundy Thursday.

This theatrical representation is so realistic and dramatic that it completely immerses you in the historical moment it seeks to recreate. The sound of drums accompanies the procession of Romans, and the enchanting music of strings fills the atmosphere of Vilanova and its monastery.

This Stations of the Cross is one of the most famous dramatizations of Holy Week in Asturias, and it takes place in the incomparable setting of Vilanova, where the monastic air makes you feel as if you were transported to the Middle Ages, the Baroque era, or the 18th century.

Furthermore, the hospitality of the people, the beauty of the landscape, and the excellent gastronomy of the area are additional attractions when it comes to witnessing this theatrical representation during Holy Week.
Tourist Interest Festival of the Principality of Asturias
San Timoteo in Luarca/Ḷḷuarca, with the "chambrón" and the "T"

The festivities of San Timoteo begin in Luarca/Ḷḷuarca on the night of August 21st, with fireworks. That night there is a dance, with different atmospheres for different tastes of the younger and older ones.

The following day, August 22nd, the pilgrimage of San Timoteo takes place. In the morning, firecrackers are set off to wake up the town. The different groups prepare their supplies and everyone heads to the chapel of San Timoteo.

The chapel is located in the so-called Campo de San Timoteo. The pilgrims go accompanied by bagpipe groups, dressed in "chambrón" and with a loaf of bread hanging from their necks.

Once they arrive at the chapel, a mass is celebrated and the saint is taken out to an exterior chapel. After the simple ceremony, the pilgrim's lunch begins in the fields surrounding the chapel.
Pilgrimage of the Holy Martyrs of Valdecuna
Festival of Touristic Interest of the Principality of Asturias
Pilgrimage of the Holy Martyrs of Valdecuna, paying homage to Saint Cosmas and Saint Damian

They were two saints who had extensive knowledge of medical and pharmaceutical science of their time and came from the East. They were called Saint Cosmas and Saint Damian, and over time they gained a reputation for performing miracles, which led to the devotion and popular memory turning the Pilgrimage of the Holy Martyrs of Valdecuna, in Mieres, into one of the most famous in Asturias.

Every September 27th, the Valley of Cuna and Cenera fills with thousands of pilgrims ready to attend the mass, and afterwards, everyone settles in the vicinity of the sanctuary and throughout the valley to enjoy a traditional Asturian countryside meal in perfect harmony, accompanied by the finest cider.

Asturian culture, devotion in green, incredibly beautiful landscapes, and non-stop celebration. That's what the Martyrs of Valdecuna are all about, and they have a very unique feature: the popular singer-songwriter from Mieres, Víctor Manuel, composed a well-known song titled "La Romería" inspired by this festival. So it's the only pilgrimage in Asturias with an original song by an author.

Festivals and Touristic Activities of the Principality of Asturias
When June arrives - specifically the first half - Gascona Street in Oviedo/Uviéu, also known as "The Cider Boulevard," hosts one of the most unique festive events of the year: the Cider Tasting

This popular and lively gathering involves the presentation of cider products by numerous participating cider mills, who subject their ciders to the visitors' votes after tasting.

While Gascona Boulevard is usually lively, on the day of the Cider Tasting, it overflows with crowds of people, eagerly looking to taste the seasonal cider and provide their opinion as a qualified popular jury.

Gascona Street, one of the oldest and most traditional streets in the capital of Asturias, has its origins linked to the tradition of the Camino de Santiago (Way of St. James), and nowadays, it is one of the most visited streets in all of Asturias by locals and foreigners alike, who come there eager to taste the finest Asturian cuisine and the best cider.

The qualities of this street and its hospitality never disappoint, quite the opposite, and the Cider Tasting is one of those occasions when Gascona showcases its excellence.
Festival of Tourist Interest of the Principality of Asturias
Gastronomic days held to coincide with the feast of Santa Bárbara

This is a highly original event because it focuses on a gastronomic activity that is deeply rooted in Asturias, namely the tasting of a good Asturian stew, but which in the Turón Valley has specific peculiarities as it is a "poorer, more watered-down stew, with more fat to make it fartuque and with some crumbled beans to fatten the broth", as the locals say.

These peculiarities are such that some culinary critics and popular wisdom have given it a name of its own: 'Pote minero de Turón'.
These days, which have been held for more than twenty-five years, coinciding with the festivity of Santa Bárbara - patron saint of miners -, take place in one of the most representative valleys of mining and industrial heritage in Asturias.

In fact, the Pozu Santa Bárbara was declared an Asset of Cultural Interest in 2010, and can be visited with a guided tour. Furthermore, the entire natural environment has been declared a Protected Landscape of the Cuencas Mineras.

The religious manifestations of this festival include a mass sung by the Miners' Choir and the procession of Santa Bárbara. There is also an emotional ceremony with a floral offering in memory of the miners who died in the mines of the Turón Valley.
Festival of Touristic Interest of the Principality of Asturia
Jira to Trasona Reservoir in Corvera de Asturias, Asturian gastronomy by the edge of the most sports-oriented waters

The Jira in Asturias is always a countryside meal and directly connects with our tradition of combining gastronomy, nature, and celebration. The Jira to Trasona Reservoir in the municipality of Corvera de Asturias is very special for several reasons. The first one is because it is linked to May 1st, Labor Day, and that's how it originated. Its birth is connected to the large contingent of workers who, since the 1950s, inhabited the area working in the steel industry. And it has been perpetuated ever since. The goal is to enjoy the homemade Asturian cuisine while enjoying bagpipes, folk groups, and the open-air dance.

Furthermore, another reason that makes this festival unique is that it takes place in the surroundings of Trasona Reservoir, well-known in Spain and abroad for being a training and high-performance venue for elite athletes in canoeing and rowing disciplines.

So, the Jira to Trasona Reservoir brings together Asturian, metallurgical, and sports traditions in a friendly popular gathering by the reservoir, amidst a pleasant landscape.
Festival of Touristic Interest in the Principality of Asturias

This bonfire represents the quintessence of popular tradition linked to Celtic Beltane, combining mythology, belief, rites of passage, and a deep connection with the creative cultures of the Atlantic Arc

Another characteristic that makes it unique is that it is an artistic bonfire, designed by renowned sculptors, constituting one of the most authentic examples of land art found in Asturias.

Simultaneously with the bonfire celebration, other cultural activities take place in parallel, such as the traditional decoration of fountains, folk music performances, mythology workshops and seminars, ethnographic conferences, and a lively atmosphere of Celtic and Asturian culture.

This artistic bonfire, with over twenty-five years of history, adds authenticity and flavor to the beginning of summer in Asturias.
Tourist interest festival of the Principality of Asturias
San Roque Festivities in Llanes, the great symphony of Everlasting Flowers

The cry of "Long live San Roque and Perru!" is unmistakable and identifies that the San Roque Festivities in Llanes have begun and they are here to stay with different events throughout the month of August, although the Grand Day is on the 16th of this month. The Everlasting Flower is the emblem of the San Roque faction since the late 19th century and continues to fill the town of Llanes with fragrance and celebration during these festivities.

The Pilgrim Dance, the bagpipe bands festival, and the open-air dances in Vega de la Portilla are traditions forever associated with San Roque of Llanes. It is a festival as genuine as it is ancient, with roots dating back to the 13th century, linked to the Coastal Camino de Santiago and the Pilgrims' Hospice that the town had. Tradition tells us that the pilgrimages in honor of San Roque were a way for the people of Llanes to show hospitality and welcome to the countless Jacobean pilgrims who made a stop in the town.

Over time, new elements have been added to the rituals, and different activities have been incorporated, but not a trace of the essence of the San Roque spirit has been erased. This essence is based on welcoming strangers without distinction of social classes and devotion to San Roque. In short, it is a true classic among the traditions of Llanes and Asturias.
Festival of Touristic Interest of the Principality of Asturias
Vaqueira Festival in Braña de Aristébanu: discovering the history and traditions of the Vaqueiros

The Vaqueira Festival, also known as "Vaqueirada," is celebrated every year on the last Sunday of July in Braña de Aristébanu, between Tineo and Valdés. It is one of the most ethnic and original festivals in all of Asturias, as it becomes a informative homage to the life and customs of the Vaqueiros de Alzada, even featuring a real wedding following Vaqueira traditions.

The Vaqueiros were and still are an ethnic and cultural group in Asturias, with ancestral origins that are still subject to research. They were transhumant shepherds who spent the summer in the brañas (high mountain pastures) with their livestock, taking advantage of the grazing areas in the mountain passes. In winter, they would return to their winter villages with their livestock and belongings.

The Vaqueiros intermarried and developed a unique culture and folklore, which has remained unchanged throughout the centuries. They primarily inhabited and still inhabit the western region of Asturias.

Attending the Vaqueira Festival is like watching an anthropology documentary, but with festivities and joy. It is a very curious, different, and lively celebration.
Festival of Touristic Interest of the Principality of Asturias
The Shepherd's Festival in La Vega (Lake Enol), pays tribute to the life and history of an Exemplary Village

A common characteristic of most Asturian festivals is the beauty and friendliness of the landscape and its people. The Shepherd's Festival in La Vega (Lake Enol), in the municipality of Cangas de Onís, is a clear example of a spectacular environment, as it takes place in one of the heartlands of the Picos de Europa National Park, which is also a Biosphere Reserve.

The Covadonga Lakes are one of the most well-known locations in the Park, largely due to the epic cycling feats that have taken place there, broadcasted to the whole world. On this occasion, the homage is dedicated to the Shepherds of Picos de Europa, a group that was named Exemplary Village of Asturias years ago.

This festival is celebrated every year on July 25th and begins with an open-air mass at the Chapel of the Good Shepherd. Next, the Council of Shepherds gathers to distribute pastures equitably and to elect the Regidor (an honorary position). Following that, there are rural sports, crafts, bagpipe music, festivities, finger-licking gastronomy featuring delicious Cabrales or Gamonéu cheese, and the highlight of the day: the climb to the Porra de Enol.

It's a unique day to immerse oneself in the Picos de Europa and its shepherding culture. As if that weren't enough, the night of the 24th is the only night of the year when free camping is allowed.
Lamb Festival at Prau Llagüezos, gastronomy in the midst of nature

The Lamb Festival, held at Prau Llagüezos, where the municipalities of Lena and Quirós converge, is also a unique event. Unique because it is very rare to have a collective roast of lambs of this kind and size.

Furthermore, the roast is done in the Argentine style, a technique introduced by a returning Asturian immigrant from the area. As if that weren't enough, the setting is breathtaking: the summit of Monte de La Cobertoria, in the heart of the Sierra del Aramo. This mountain range is one of the great and mythical mountains of central Asturias, whose history is written with human and sporting feats.

This collective roast, accompanied by music and Asturian gastronomy, takes place in a flat meadow, complete with a fountain and mountain lodge, and even with remains of burial sites probably of medieval origin. It's an environment where the oldest history, the most vibrant nature, and the mixed Asturian and Latin American traditions come together. An eclecticism that makes this festival an unforgettable moment.
Festival of Tourist Interest of the Principality of Asturias
The only event dedicated to stuffed peppers in Asturias, with a long tradition of forty years

It is a unique festival as it is the only event dedicated to stuffed peppers in Asturias, with a long tradition of forty years.

In addition to the gastronomic manifestations, which are the essence of the festival, there is a wide program of cultural events. The celebration lasts several days during which the Stuffed Peppers Proclamation is presented with the delivery of the Golden Pepper, in addition to concerts, folk performances, stuffed pepper contest, theatrical performances, flea market, Asturian songs, soccer, bowling, games for children, etc.

There is a lively atmosphere and animation in this gastronomic and cultural tribute to the stuffed bell pepper filled with meat or tuna. In short, it is a festival that connects with the culinary art culture of the mining basin and the celebration of friendship around a healthy and always surprising table.
Festival of Touristic Interest of the Principality of Asturias
The Humanitarians' Festival in Morea/Moreda, solidarity and unique gastronomy

For over a hundred years, specifically since 1905, every November 11th (feast day of Saint Martin of Tours), Morea/Moreda dresses up in style to celebrate what is considered one of the most popular and classic events of the Asturian autumn.

This festival, which includes typical rituals such as mass, a parade of floats, and traditional Asturian folklore, is very original for several reasons. Firstly, because it arises from community association with a social and supportive purpose of aiding the underprivileged. Secondly, because the festival's typical cuisine - primarily fabada (Asturian bean stew) and casadielles (a type of pastry) - also includes panchón, the quintessential dessert from Aller, which is based on spelt bread (also authentically Asturian). And thirdly, because few associations that create such a unique festival also hold the distinction of being an Exemplary Village of Asturias.

Therefore, the Humanitarians represent the perfect combination of solidarity, and the Asturian tradition of enjoying good food and drink.
Festival of Touristic Interest of the Principality of Asturias
Painted Eggs Festival in La Pola Siero, an artistic tradition

This festival is always celebrated on the Tuesday following Easter Sunday. From early morning, the most historic and central area of La Pola Siero is filled with beautifully decorated stalls where you can admire and purchase Painted Eggs of various sizes and designs. Many of them feature motifs related to traditional Asturian culture, as well as different phrases and symbols.

A very special moment of this festival is the Blessing of the Painted Eggs in the Town Hall square, and from that moment on, cider flows, good food, bagpipe music, and celebration take place, culminating in a late-night dance party that lasts until dawn.

The tradition of Painted Eggs has an uncertain origin and dates back several centuries. Specifically in Siero, it has been passed down orally from generation to generation, and it may be linked - this is only a hypothesis - to the arrival of workers from Central Europe who came to work in the mines in both Siero and Langreo, where the first coal deposits were explored.
El Bollo Festival in Avilés, the liveliest lunch in the historic center of the Villa del Adelantado

The El Bollo Festival in Avilés is the perfect culmination of the Easter festivities in Avilés, also known as Villa del Adelantado in clear reference to the illustrious figure of Don Pedro Menéndez, sailor and founder of the first city in the United States.

The festival takes place on Easter Sunday and Monday. On Sunday, there is a parade of floats and folk groups, and on Monday, after the mass at San Nicolás de Bari and the corresponding proclamation, there is a massive communal meal in the streets of the Old Town of Avilés. The truth is that there is nothing quite like it in all of Asturias: thousands of people seated to enjoy various Asturian delicacies, with one of the most important Historic Centers in Spain as the backdrop.

By the way, the festival gets its name from the "bollo" or cake given by the godparents to their godchildren on Easter Sunday.
The Fiesta del Bollo in Avilés
Tourist Interest Festival of the Principality of Asturias
The Festivity of La Ponte combines antiquity, identity, a sense of tradition, abundant fun, and Asturian spirit. It is a tribute to the historical evolution in rural Asturias

Popular tradition places the origins of this festival in the early 16th century, setting it apart from other known celebrations called "fiestas de prao." One of its central events is the only livestock fair held in the municipality of Pravia, which is also one of the oldest in all of Asturias.

The festival also features the Bolo Batiente championship, oxen dragging, horse ribbon race, and a sung Mass in Asturian language, accompanied by bagpipe music.

One of the most striking aspects of this celebration is its ability to endure over time, overcoming various challenges and social changes, while still showcasing the authenticity and purity of rural Asturias amidst the incomparable beauty of the Arango Valley.

Over the years and until today, La Ponte has been organized as a festival for everyone. There is a livestock market, along with various activities and entertainment for all to enjoy.
Tourist Interest Festival of the Principality of Asturias
With over fifteen years of history, it is the most traditional and prestigious festival in Europe

With over fifteen years of history, it is the most traditional and prestigious festival in Europe, and it is currently among the top three in the world. It was also the first in Asturias to combine sports and leisure activities.

Although the origin and essence of this celebration are sports-related, every day of the festival is an ideal moment to enjoy not only surfing but also the spectacular natural environment of Salinas, as well as other complementary activities such as concerts, screenings, adapted surfing, or children's workshops.

The festival is deeply rooted in the rich surfing and sports tradition of Salinas and its beach, which have been pioneers in the practice of this sport in northern Spain.

This festival is a clear example of how, in addition to watching and practicing great surfing, you can fully enjoy a lively atmosphere where there is something to do at all times of the day and night.
Festivals and Activities of Touristic Interest of the Principality of Asturias
The Boal Honey Fair is a benchmark event for the industry in Asturias. With over three decades of history, it has become a prominent event in Asturias' leisure and festive calendar.

This fair is an example of promoting local producers and traders around the star product of this municipality: honey. Hence the commercial, cultural, and recreational importance of this event that enlivens the municipality of Boal every autumn, usually around November.

The streets of Boal/Bual's capital are filled with the atmosphere, featuring a market of local products that are always healthy, delicious, and generally eco-friendly. Boal's honey, considered exquisite and very natural, serves as its flagship product.

A diverse program of cultural and tourist activities enhances the appeal of this fair, which is also an ideal opportunity to explore the capital of the municipality and other nearby places of interest.

Boal combines beautiful landscapes, ancestral culture, a rich history, tasty cuisine, and hospitable people, all sweetened with the delicious honey of the region.
Festival of Touristic Interest in the Principality of Asturias

Spring arrives in Grado dressed in its best attire, with all its colors and flavors. The "Primera Flor de Grado," the First Flower of Grado, and the competition for Asturian IGP Faba Beans and related products, declared of Touristic Interest in Asturias, takes place on the weekend following Easter

This festival is closely linked to the great commercial and market tradition that the town of Grau/Grado has had since medieval times. For this reason, the First Flower of Grado is one of the most emblematic markets in the town and has been celebrated for decades. It is the first major trade fair of the year and always heralds a prosperous spring, hence its original and distinctive name.

Initially, it was dedicated to the sale of ham, gaining well-deserved fame for this product within and beyond Asturias. Over time, it abandoned its thematic character and now it is a market where you can find all kinds of products, mostly natural, organic, and homemade, in line with the richness and fertility of the land in Grado and the talent and ingenuity of its inhabitants, who are respectful and well-versed in ancestral traditions, both gastronomic and cultural.

Therefore, the First Flower of Grado is a significant social event, always lively, where you can enjoy an exceptional market while experiencing the hospitality and expertise of the locals in the town and surrounding area. It is an opportunity to eat well, stroll around, purchase products that you won't find in other markets, or enjoy a vermouth on one of the colorful terraces in the historic center of this town. In Grau/Grado, nobody is a stranger, and if in doubt, ask the thousands of pilgrims who make a stop on their Camino Primitivo in this town. All of this becomes evident during the celebration of the First Flower of Grado.
Touristic Interest Festival of the Principality of Asturias
This sporting, tourist, and cultural event held in Lluanco/Luanco is one of the major summer gatherings in this beautiful fishing village where tennis has deep roots and tradition

The Luanco Beach Tennis Tournament is a sporting and cultural event that takes place in Lluanco/Luanco, the capital of the Gozón municipality. Its rich history dates back to the early 1970s, and since then, although with some interruptions, it has been held on La Ribera beach, being the only exhibition tennis tournament organized on the sandy shore during low tide.

Bleachers with a capacity exceeding 2,000 people are set up on the beach, and together with the natural conditions of the environment, the capacity can reach almost 3,000 spectators. Additionally, the venue has artificial lighting for matches to be played at night.

The Luanco Beach Tennis Tournament has great prestige in the tennis field, both nationally and internationally, and this, combined with its unique characteristics, positions the village of Lluanco/Luanco as a true sports mecca. The lively and playful atmosphere surrounding the event is the perfect finishing touch to this Touristic Interest Festival of the Principality of Asturias.
Festival of Touristic Interest of the Principality of Asturias
San Roque in Tineo, the most Jacobean festival

They are the most important festivities in Tineo and are celebrated in the Campo de San Roque and in the town, in mid-August. The main days of the festival are August 15th (Bollo Day) and August 16th (Grand Day of San Roque), but the festivities begin a few days earlier with Peñas Day and end on August 18th (End of Festivities).

To trace the origin of the San Roque festivities, we have to go back to the founding of the Chapel in the Campo de San Roque in the 14th century when pilgrims on their way to Santiago de Compostela paid tribute to the saint on his feast day.

In the 19th century, on August 16th, people with livestock, especially sheep and goats, would gather around the hermitage to buy or sell, and around them, people from the town would sell boiled potatoes, hazelnuts, spelt bread, and other local products.

Today, the tradition of eating in the countryside continues, and the appearance of the "peñas" (in the last decade of the 20th century) has significantly increased the festivities. Barrels of cider and wine are now a common sight in the countryside, alongside baskets filled with typical Tinetense food: ham, loin, chosco (a type of cured pork), and all kinds of sausages and meat products. It is and will remain the great moment of family union and one of the main events of the festival.

The Tineo Bowling Championship, which is still held at the Campo de San Roque bowling alley, remains essential, as well as the Carriage Parade, which takes place on August 18th and has been a tradition since the 20th century, along with the selection of the Festival Queens.

These festivities are the annual gathering for families and the return of absent Tinetense people.
Festival of Touristic Interest of the Principality of Asturias

The town of Cue, located 2 kilometers from the capital of the municipality, Llanes, celebrates its patron saint festival on June 24th.

After days of hard and intense work by the locals, on the 24th the streets of the town are adorned with floral carpets that lead to each of the two altars, and the processions pass through them in the early afternoon after the mass. The procession is welcomed in each neighborhood with a generous display of fireworks. The creation of the carpets involves a friendly competition between the Upper Neighborhood and the Lower Neighborhood to make the most impressive and colorful one.

Each neighborhood has its own particular characteristics in the making of their carpets. In the Lower Neighborhood, whose floral symbol is the everlasting flower, other perishable materials such as cut grass and peat are also used. In the Upper Neighborhood, whose floral symbol is the carnation, dyed sand, ashes, and reed mace are also used. Both neighborhoods prominently feature religious motifs.

The Sacramental is undoubtedly one of the most colorful, aromatic, and ritualistic festivals in all of Eastern Asturias.
Festival of Touristic Interest of the Principality of Asturias
Marine procession of San Juan in L'Arena, the blessing of the Cantabrian Sea

This original and unique procession takes place on June 24th, the feast day of San Juan. The central event, with a centuries-old tradition, takes place through the most central streets of the coastal town of L'Arena, which are filled with atmosphere and joy on that day.

One of the most emotional moments of this procession is the blessing of the waters of the Cantabrian Sea, marking the beginning of the tuna fishing season. At that moment, the sailors carrying San Juan, San Telmo, and the Virgin of Carmen approach the port for the priest to proceed with the blessing of the waters.

The procession is accompanied by the sounds of bagpipe bands and by the children who have celebrated their First Communion this year. It stands out from other marine processions in that all the participants are dressed in the summer uniform of the Navy, a tradition deeply rooted in the past that gives a very different atmosphere to this festival.

Furthermore, the beauty of L'Arena and the surroundings of the Nalón estuary and Los Quebrantos Beach complete a magnificent setting for this celebration.
Festival of Tourist Interest of the Principality of Asturias
. First landing of Charles V in Tazones, a true royal odyssey

On September 19, 1517, the young Prince Charles of Habsburg, who would become Emperor Charles V and the most powerful man on Earth at that time, disembarked in Tazones with his court, unplanned and driven by the adverse sea conditions at that moment. The young Flemish prince, son of Joanna the Mad and Philip the Handsome, had a unique reception from the humble fishing village that was this seaside town five hundred years ago.

At first, they mistook him for a pirate...

Once his royal presence was identified, everything changed, and the villagers showered the young emperor with attention. He was captivated by the hospitality of the people and the beauty of the land he had arrived in.

Soon, this casual and unexpected arrival turned into a celebration...

Since there was no place to accommodate so many noble guests, the emperor decided to stay in Villaviciosa, where he remained for three days.

This curious anecdote has given rise to the Festival of the Landing of Charles V, celebrated for several decades, which takes place on the first day in Tazones and the following day in Villaviciosa. It enjoys great popular participation, with many people dressing in period costumes, and hundreds of visitors observe the entire historic scene attentively. An event that has earned the municipality of Villaviciosa the inclusion in the Cultural Itinerary of the Council of Europe's "European Routes of Emperor Charles V."
Our Lady of Carmen - La Descarga
Festival of tourist interest in the Principality of Asturias
The grandest tribute to the Virgin in the form of gunpowder

Our Lady of Carmen is one of the most revered figures throughout Asturias, not only along the coastal strip - she is the patroness of sailors - but also in the inland areas. As an example, we have Cangas del Narcea. Every July 16th, the town of Cangas vibrates with the famous "Descarga" (Gunfire). Around eight o'clock in the evening, when the Virgin's procession crosses the old bridge on its way to the chapel, the sky over Cangas fills with fireworks and gunpowder for several minutes. The sky turns white, and the intoxicating scent of gunpowder fills every corner.

The sensation of the "Descarga" is unique and indescribable, and it can only be fully appreciated by experiencing it. It is the eternal tribute of the Cangas groups to the Virgin and to those who are no longer with us, but somehow come back to life in that moment. As night falls, the artistic and emotional midnight fireworks provide the perfect ending to an emblematic festival that combines three aspects: Devotion, celebration, and art.
Our Lady of Carmen - La Descarga

Our Lady of Carmen - La Descarga
Magical Night and Esfoyón and Amagüestu Festival
Tourist Interest Festival of the Principality of Asturias
Magical Night and Esfoyón and Amagüestu Festival in Navelgas, a space of very entertaining traditions

Navelgas is a village in the municipality of Tineo, in the westernmost heart of Asturias, which somehow embodies the most traditional and magical atmosphere of Asturian villages. That's why it's no coincidence that one of the most genuine festivals about rural traditions in Asturias related to autumn is celebrated there.

The Esfoyón and Amagosto Festival accurately portrays the "esfoyones" of the past, in which the villagers would gather at a house to husk or "esfoyar" the corn from that family and then help them string and hang it on the balconies.

These gatherings were a social event where people of all ages would socialize, sing, and the younger ones would court each other. The "esfoyaza" became a big celebration where stories, legends, and traditions were shared, as the work didn't take away energy for the festivities and songs.

Currently, the Esfoyón festival begins at dusk in the neighborhood of Navelgas de Arriba, which is completely decorated for the occasion. The streets are covered with straw and illuminated with torches, and all the villagers dress in traditional clothes and prepare delicious dishes such as "frixuelos" (Asturian pancakes), chestnuts, corn cakes, stuffed rolls, freshly skimmed lard, etc.

Furthermore, different artisans - woodworkers, basket weavers, blacksmiths, etc. - set up their demonstrations under the "paneras" (typical Asturian raised granaries) and in the stables. Meanwhile, the younger ones distribute the "garutsa," homemade cherry liqueur, "orujo" (a strong alcoholic beverage), and drinks that help ward off the November cold since this festival always takes place in the first half of the month.

Throughout the night, the "panoya de oro" (golden ear) is awarded to a distinguished personality for their support of the festival and traditions.

This festival is undoubtedly an ideal opportunity to experience the most authentic rural traditions of Asturias.
Touristic Event of Interest in the Principality of Asturias
The traditional market of Oles, or a journey to the heart of Asturian traditions

The Asturian Market of Oles is an authentic journey into Asturian traditions, faithfully recreating its essence. For the past fifteen years, this market has become an unmissable summer event in the first half of August, in the central coastal area of Asturias, and in the heart of the maritime territory.

It is no coincidence that this journey to the heart of traditions takes place in Oles, as it is an area of Asturias with strong roots and Asturian cultural heritage.

Throughout the entire weekend, theatrical performances, comedians, artisans, musicians, and more bring color and atmosphere to this market, where demonstrations of crafts and artisanal trades related to jet (there are significant jet deposits in the area), wood, clay, ceramics, among others, take place. In reality, a significant part of the market's success is attributed to its role as a major gathering of artisans.
Touristic Interest Festival of the Principality of Asturias.

On the first weekend of August, San Martín de Luiña becomes a great vaqueiro (cowherd) festival, as its Vaqueiro Market is one of the major events of the Asturian summer in the western region. Multiple activities are organized around this market, including visits to the vaqueiro brañas (mountain pastures), parades, traditional cider songs, bagpipe groups, and more.

There is no shortage of moments dedicated to the traditional rural vaqueiro culture of the area. It is possible to see buelles (traditional dwellings) and carros del país (country carts), as well as a representation of a vaqueiro wedding. Not to mention the typical craftsmanship or the vaqueiro menus that can be enjoyed in the local restaurants. And, of course, there are always activities for children.

In short, it is a tribute to the vaqueiro culture and the rural world of Asturias in a privileged setting such as San Martín de Luiña. The Vaqueiro Market will transport you to another era and allow you to have a different leisure experience.
Artisan and Ecological Market of Gijón

The Artisan and Ecological Market of Gijón is a cultural, artisan, gastronomic and touristic reference in the city of Gijón/Xixón, and as such it has been consolidated after 15 years of existence

It has established itself as a benchmark for crafts, gastronomy and tourism in Gijón. The quality of its products is its main distinctive feature and attraction, together with the activities and workshops that it has been organising since it was founded sixteen years ago, which allow locals and tourists to get to know the culture and reality of Asturias in a participative and educational way.

Located in the Plaza Mayor, in the heart of Gijón/Xixón, it has become an eagerly awaited meeting point for Asturian crafts, which takes place on the second weekend of every month.

The Market is held on the second weekend of every month in Gijón/Xixón, with the exception of Easter and the long weekend of the Constitution, when it changes its usual date to coincide with these holidays due to the large number of tourists visiting the city.

The Market has a wide range of products on offer, always distinguished by their high quality. The Asturian handicrafts combine tradition and modernity. They are exclusive, unique, handmade following the patterns of ancient crafts and highly valued nationally.

The Market presents a complete sample of guilds, including jet, leather, woodcarving, weaving, embossing, jewellery, glass, stationery, painting, stone, etc.
As for gastronomy, the public can enjoy organic and traditional products, such as bread, sausages, cheeses, honey, jams, fruit and vegetables, among many others.

As part of its vocation for solidarity, the Artisan Market also offers a range of products from cooperatives in Southern countries that respect the social and environmental conditions of the countries of origin.

In addition to its quality and excellence, it is distinguished from other fairs by the uniqueness conferred by the fact that the artisans themselves are responsible for its development. The Artisan and Ecological Market Association is also working to surprise visitors with new activities, exhibitions and workshops, whose aim is to bring Asturian culture and traditions closer to the public in a participative, educational and entertaining way.
Artisan and Ecological Market of Gijón

Artisan and Ecological Market of Gijón
Gastronomic Days of the Slaughter of Amieva and Alto Sella
Festival of Tourist Interest of the Principality of Asturias
Or the eternal tribute to the oldest survival rituals

The cuisine of the slaughter (referring to the gastronomic culture of the pig that exists in Asturias), is extensive and varied, both in terms of products and recipes. And specifically in the area of Amieva and Alto Sella it is very characteristic, and for the last two decades it has been one of the great promotional attractions of this part of eastern Asturias.

These days, which are held every year every weekend in February, have been declared of Regional Tourist Interest, and have turned dishes such as liver soup, cabbage stew, borona preñada, gochu (pork) hands, tripe, stewed tongue, boronchu fritu, picadillo, or fried pork loin into true classics of the Asturian gastronomic winter, especially in mountain and village areas.

These days are a must for lovers of good food and traditional Asturian cuisine linked to ancestral traditions and survival in the rural world. They have also become the ideal excuse to enjoy rural tourism.

Festival of Tourist Interest of the Principality of Asturias
The Jornadas Gastronómicas de la Llámpara in Quintes and Quintueles (Villaviciosa) have now been held for more than thirty years, making them a classic on the Asturian gastronomic-festive calendar

Every year, around the month of May, both towns in Mali - Quintes and Quintueles - get together to organise this culinary and leisure event, which involves a large part of the local hotel and catering trade. For several days the restaurants, cider houses and eating houses in the area are bursting with tasty menus, in which the 'llámpara' (or 'lapa' in Spanish) is the queen of the table.

Varied recipes and marvellous pairings liven up the gastronomic days in an area with a great tradition of "llámpara" cuisine, given the scenic characteristics of a coastline with an abundance of rocky outcrops and cliffs.
The area also offers numerous tourist attractions, in addition to its excellent cuisine. Routes, beaches, beautiful villages, interesting civil and religious architecture, etc.

The Asturian spring has one of its most significant recreational events in these Gastronomic Days of the "Llámpara", which, year after year, make known one of the great delicacies of Asturian nature, which in this part of the coast acquires the rank of excellence.
Festival of Touristic Interest of the Principality of Asturias
Asturian culture and devotion, fun and revelry

San Antonio de Padua Festival in Cangues d'Onís/Cangas de Onís adorn the city and fill the atmosphere, serving as the perfect prelude to summer in a place that is always bustling with locals and visitors. Although the festivities last for several days, the main day is June 13th, the feast day of the saint.

The streets and corners of Cangues are adorned with Asturian flags, banners, thousands of people wearing traditional costumes, folk groups, bagpipe bands, and a lot of excitement. Fireworks mark the beginning of a day of celebration that includes mass, a procession, and the auctioning of the "ramu" (offering of flowers and bread), where the vermouth session and meals with family and friends from all over the world become a renewed ritual every year.

Both in Cangues d'Arriba and in the city center, the festivities continue until the early hours of the morning, and an important aspect is the hospitality of the people of Cangues, where no one feels like a stranger or excluded from the celebration.

On the previous night, in the oak grove near the chapel of San Antonio, the famous "joguera" takes place, and it is quite a spectacle to witness the impressive leaps over the fire by locals and visitors.
Festival of Touristic Interest of the Principality of Asturias
Oviedo/Uviéu, the capital of Asturias, is a city where gastronomy stands out as one of the great attractions that can be enjoyed on a daily basis

There are also numerous events showcasing Asturian cuisine in the life of Oviedo. One of the most prominent is the celebration of El Desarme, one of the most significant and deeply rooted gastronomic events in Asturias.

For over half a century, the city's restaurants and cider houses dawn in their best culinary attire to offer the famous Desarme menu, which is savored every October 19th. It consists of chickpeas with cod and spinach, Asturian-style tripe, and rice pudding. Simply delicious and hearty, it is a unique opportunity to commemorate a historical event dating back to the first half of the 19th century, which is linked to the Carlist Wars.

In the context of this festival, the Brotherhood of El Desarme was founded in 2012, with the firm purpose of promoting this deeply rooted and flavorful celebration. It is an ideal occasion for the exaltation of friendship around the dining table.
Tourist Interest Festival of the Principality of Asturias
The originality and a significant part of the appeal of this event are rooted in the accompanying activities

The reading of the proclamation is one of the moments that generates great anticipation, as it is usually delivered by a personality - whether local, regional, or national - associated with the world of gastronomy, politics, or media. And as a grand finale, this event is accompanied by a bagpipe band and a choir.

During the proclamation ceremony, the prize for the International Photography Competition "The Mine and the Sea" is also awarded, and visitors can enjoy an exhibition showcasing the most outstanding works from this competition. The exhibition later becomes itinerant, traveling to different locations in Asturias.

Furthermore, there is a tasting of fabada during the three days of the festival in the restaurants of La Felguera (Langreo).

And, of course, another festive attraction is the fabada contest.

Undoubtedly, apart from the lively gastronomic atmosphere in La Felguera, the uniqueness of this celebration is also rooted in the product: fabes are inherently Asturian and one of the main culinary symbols of Asturias.

With nearly 40 years of history, this festival takes place during the second weekend of December.
Festival of Touristic Interest of the Principality of Asturias
Asturias Peoples' Day in Navelgas, an immersion in Asturian culture

The purpose of Asturias Peoples' Day is to foster the brotherhood and solidarity among the different Asturian communities, showcasing what they have in common as well as their unique characteristics. Ultimately, it aims to promote a sense of inclusive Asturian identity that is open to the world.

In each edition, a village in Asturias is honored and presented with the Paloma de la Fraternidad (Dove of Fraternity). The people of the honored village are warmly welcomed in Navelgas, reflecting the hospitality and defining traits of this village and, in general, the rural Asturian world. Representatives and residents from previously twinned villages, as well as other visitors and tourists, join in the festivities, creating a spontaneous atmosphere of joyful coexistence.

During the official ceremony, the Chosco de Oro (Golden Chosco) is awarded, symbolizing two of our most cherished traditions. It recognizes individuals and institutions that excel in promoting, disseminating, and defending Asturias.

The Silver Blueberry, on the other hand, distinguishes individuals or groups who stand out with their contributions in the fields of ethnography, folklore, gastronomy, music, and other cultural expressions.

The program typically includes a Reception for Awardees and Authorities, a Parade of Folk Groups and invited groups, and the Award Ceremony. The day is filled with lively entertainment and other recreational and cultural activities.

The celebration usually takes place on the last weekend of August.
The Feast of Santo Cristo del Amparo
Festival of Touristic Interest of the Principality of Asturias
The Feast of Santo Cristo del Amparo in Nueva de Llanes, a brilliant culmination of the summer

The Feast of Santo Cristo del Amparo in Nueva somehow marks the end of the summer season. Every September 13th and 14th, this famous village of recognized beauty celebrates one of its most characteristic festivals.

As is often the case in the villages and hamlets of Llanes, traditions - especially those related to dances and music - are of utmost importance, and the Christ festival is no exception. On the 13th, bagpipe bands and regional dances take center stage, especially the Dance of the Christ.

The 14th is the main day, with a mass and impressive procession. The dances continue to liven up the festival, and the Dance of the Christ is repeated. In the afternoon, the Dance of the Married Couples takes the spotlight, and all the joy culminates in a grand open-air dance, where the final highlight is the garlic soup.
The Feast of Santo Cristo del Amparo
Festival of Touristic Interest of the Principality of Asturias
Picadillo and Sabadiego Festival in Noreña, or the most festive celebration of charcuterie

Noreña is the charcuterie capital of Asturias, with a great tradition in the production of meat products, particularly those derived from pork. Not in vain, this resourceful animal has a monument in the heart of this town, which has a monumental appearance.

The streets, taverns, and restaurants of Noreña showcase the best of their kitchens and their people to celebrate in grand style this heartfelt and gastronomic homage to two of the most important products in their culinary knowledge and tradition.

Both the picadillo of Noreña and the sabadiego are unique in the world, and this is well explained by the members of the Sabadiego Order, who also have a well-deserved prominence in this festival.

To accompany the rich gastronomy, there is a comprehensive program of music, concerts, and other cultural activities that continuously liven up the town.
Festival of Touristic Interest of the Principality of Asturias
Bollu Festival: Long live La Peruyal!

The Bollu Festival, also known as La Peruyal, is celebrated in Arriondas/Les Arriondes, the capital of the Parres council.

This festival, which dates back to the first half of the 20th century, represents the essence of a traditional Asturian pilgrimage, where the typical Asturian atmosphere prevails and the bollu preñao (bread roll filled with chorizo) and cider bring a lively touch to the celebration.

The parade of floats is another distinctive feature of this festival, where joy overflows in every corner, including the historic neighborhood of La Peruyal, the epicenter of this celebration.

Moreover, it serves as the perfect prelude to the Piraguas Festival, which takes place a few days later.
Festival of Touristic Interest of the Principality of Asturias
Alba Festival in Quirós, a devotion with the best views

The Alba Festival, in honor of the Virgin of Alba, the patron saint of Quirós, is celebrated every year on August 15th at the Alba Hermitage, located above the town of Salceo.

Nestled in the heart of the Aramo Mountains, at an altitude of about 1090 meters, it has good access through an asphalted track. This Hermitage, known for its devotion and history, offers spectacular views of the entire municipality of Quirós.

On the occasion of the Alba Festival, a procession takes place, accompanied by bagpipes and drums, and after the procession, a mass is held. It is worth noting that the mass is usually sung in the Quirosan language.

Afterwards, a countryside meal takes place, followed by various activities such as horseback ribbon races, the contest of spelt bread, the display of cow taming, etc. It is a complete ritual that is repeated successfully and attracts a large number of people year after year.

In addition, it is customary to camp near the Hermitage in the days leading up to the festival, thus celebrating the traditional popular festivities.
Santu Medé Festival (Saint Emeterius and Saint Celedonius)
Festival of Touristic Interest of the Principality of Asturias
It is an ancestral festival, whose most probable origin lies in the Christianization of a spring festival

It is an original celebration in Pimiango, joined by the residents of Ribadedeva and also people who come from other parts of Asturias and from outside.

The festival is currently of a religious nature and is dedicated to the martyrs Saint Emeterius and Saint Celedonius.

It consists of a pilgrimage from the village of Pimiango to the Hermitage of San Emeterio. It is a walk of over two kilometers through an exceptionally beautiful landscape where you will encounter the Pindal Cave (World Heritage Site), the San Emeterio lighthouse (the easternmost in Asturias), the Monastery of Tina, and the most coastal stretch of the Camino de Santiago.

The festival, which includes the traditional offering of the "ramu" (flower bouquet) and its auction, culminates with a countryside tour - the only one in the municipality - where you can enjoy the music of bagpipe bands, performances by folk groups, as well as cider and typical Asturian food.
San Pedrín de la Cueva Festival
Festival of Touristic Interest of the Principality of Asturias
San Pedrín de la Cueva Festival in Sariego: the fusion of nature, culture, and sports

The San Pedrín festival is a classic event in the Asturian summer. Due to the characteristics of this festival, it can be said that we are facing a perfect example of a balanced fusion of nature, culture, and sports.

San Pedrín de la Cueva is well-known for its famous procession, in which the Saint is taken from the chapel where it is usually kept to a natural cave, where Mass is celebrated in the Asturian language.

The festive atmosphere is vibrant: bagpipe bands, choral concerts, traditional cuisine, and to top it all off, a full program of festivities including a traditional dance, folk music, as well as other recreational and sporting activities such as the motocross race, well-known at a national and even international level. There are also floats, in short, several days of non-stop celebration.
San Pedrín de la Cueva Festival
Fiesta of Our Lady of Carmen and Carmín
Festival of Touristic Interest of the Principality of Asturias
Fiesta of Our Lady of Carmen and Carmín: the pilgrimage of Asturias

Talking about Carmín is like talking about something well-known and traditional: everything has been said or written by researchers at some point, but there is always something new to say. This festival was born in 1695, the year when Andrés Quintanal and his wife María García, residents of La Pola Siero and devotees of the Virgin of Carmen, funded the construction of Les Campes, a hermitage dedicated to this Virgin, forming a Brotherhood under the patronage of Carmel.

Chronicles tell that it cost them 12,000 reales, and it was blessed on July 17th of that same year, the day after the feast day of the patron saint, and it was proposed to celebrate the festival in 1696. The hermitage was located among the chestnut trees that occupied the current Plaza de Les Campes, next to the path followed by pilgrims heading to Santiago de Compostela. The numerous members of the brotherhood, coming from all over the province, celebrated their patron saint on the Sunday following July 16th, if that date did not fall on a Sunday, holding a procession that included, among other demonstrations, the dance known as "Los Danzantes" until the first decade of this century, as well as the display of numerous "Ramos" (flower bouquets), a tradition that lasted until 1879 when it was lost.

However, the attendance of the brotherhood on Sunday was so significant that it became necessary to organize a second festival on Tuesday, the day of the market in Pola de Siero, so that the devotees of the municipality could also celebrate their patron saint. These people, who were used to waking up early for the weekly market, would arrive in the town carrying food, which mainly consisted of eel pie and other homemade dishes that they would enjoy in the same "castañeu" (chestnut grove) once the religious acts and subsequent dances were finished. Needless to say, with their bellies full, they would continue with songs and dances, culminating at dusk with the "Danza Prima," whose refrain "¡Viva la Virgen del Carmen!" (Long live the Virgin of Carmen!) exalted the patron saint. The rise in popularity of the pilgrimage on Tuesday, at the expense of the one on Sunday, which we can consider as the embryo and origin of the current Carmín, was solely due to the secular component, acting as a driving force for changes in collective mentalities, gradually absorbing the religious component until it was nullified, leaving it exclusively to the Sunday celebration, consisting of a solemn mass and procession in honor of Our Lady of Carmen. Although these dates from the 17th century, the origins of the El Carmín pilgrimage may seem distant, it still remains, in essence, the same as that of the Tuesday pilgrimage, with the logical changes imposed by the times. One of these changes was the date of the celebration: it moved from Tuesday to the Monday following July 16th, the feast day of the Virgin of Carmen.

The fundamental reason for this change was the destruction of the patron saint's hermitage during the French invasion, as recorded in 1815 in one of the Church's factory books, signed by Don Diego Fernández Linares, the parish priest of La Pola Siero. It is also known from the documentation that the bell from the hermitage was given to melt a new one for the parish church, as the previous one was broken.

This historical summary clearly demonstrates the great tradition of a festival considered one of the major pilgrimages in Asturias, which fully enlivens the Asturian summer, not only on the day of the actual festival but also in the preceding days with various recreational and cultural activities.
