Festival of Our Lady of El Carbayu
Festival of Touristic Interest of the Principality of Asturias
A journey to the Middle Ages

On September 8th, the people of Langreo and its surrounding areas celebrate the main day of their municipality, and the chosen location is the Chapel of El Carbayu. There lies the patron saint of the municipality, and that is where the most important countryside pilgrimage of Langreo takes place, integrating the most representative elements of the typical Asturian festival: the traditional attire of Asturian folklore, along with the offering of the "puya'l ramu" (a religious offering) and a meal in the meadow with friends and family.

The Virgin of El Carbayu symbolizes the unity between the towns and their people, and it is an ancient medieval devotion. Interestingly, her figure is located on a baroque altarpiece on top of a tree trunk, as the legend goes that the Virgin appeared centuries ago on an oak tree (carbayu in Asturian), expressing her will to have a temple built in that specific location, which overlooks the entire Langreo Valley.

Thus, legend, tradition, and festivity come together in Langreo.
Festival of Our Lady of El Carbayu
Festival of Tourist Interest of the Principality of Asturias
Turnip Festival in Sotrondio, a moment of ancestral flavors

The town of Sotrondio in San Martín del Rey Aurelio is the cozy setting for the Turnip Festival. This original gastronomic festival showcases the potential of culinary tradition and creative capacity in the heart of the Nalón Valley. In few places in Asturias can you taste such a tasty and healthy turnip stew as the one that comes out of the Sotrondio kitchens during the days of the festival.

The celebration coincides with the feast of Saint Martin of Tours, the patron saint of the municipality, and the main events include the solemn mass, the "puya'l ramu" (a traditional custom), the bagpipe and drum processions, the traditional dances, and of course, the presentation of the Golden Turnip, which is awarded each year to a prominent personality.

Therefore, the main day of the festival is November 11th, and on that day as well as the rest of the celebration days, the restaurants, cider houses, and eateries in Sotrondio offer the traditional turnip menu, which is usually accompanied by a second course of tripe stew and for dessert, a typical sweet such as casadielles, fayuelos, or rice pudding... A complete menu for the brave!

The turnip stew, starring this succulent vegetable, is prepared with a good "compango" (assorted meats), giving the dish the necessary consistency to combat the cold weather of the season.

Although the origin of this unique and original tradition is not known for certain, there is a legend that says it was King Aurelio of the Asturian monarchy, back in the year 774, who gave rise to this tradition by making this municipality the capital of the kingdom, and at that time turnips were an appreciated tuber in the culinary habits of the era.Gastronomy and legend come together in the Turnip Festival!
Festival of Touristic Interest of the Principality of Asturias

The "Exconxuraos" of Llanera commemorate a historical event that took place in the municipality a long time ago, and its commemoration was revived by the residents of this central Asturian town just over a decade ago.

Around the year 1408, without being able to pinpoint the exact date, the residents of the municipality of Llanera, under the jurisdiction of the Episcopal See of Oviedo, tired of enduring the "aggravios e sinrazones" (grievances and injustices) inflicted upon them "by some commanders of Don Guillén," the bishop at the time, openly rebelled against his authority. As a consequence, they were subjected to the severe canonical penalties typical of such cases, with a sentence of excommunication and interdict pronounced upon the inhabitants of the rebellious municipality and its entire territory. The bells of the churches in the municipality fell silent. For four years, their doors remained closed, and the clergy who served them ceased to conduct Sunday services and provide spiritual care to their parishioners, deprived of the consoling final blessing of the Church and the right to receive ecclesiastical burial.

On February 17, 1412, Don Guillén passed away in Oviedo. Shortly thereafter, in June of the same year, Diego Ramírez de Guzmán, a Leonese, was appointed as the Bishop of Oviedo. On June 26, the Dean and the chapter of the Oviedo Church conferred full powers upon Alvar Fernández, the archdeacon of Tineo, Alvar Pérez, the precentor, and Alvar Fernández, a canon and bachelor of decrees, so that, on behalf of the new prelate's general vicar, they could adopt measures aimed at ending the existing tensions between the bishop, the Dean, and the chapter on one side, and "all the noble and free men residing in the municipality of Llanera" on the other. Two days after the chapter meeting, on Wednesday, July 27, in the presence of several notaries and representatives of the local nobility, following a formal summons by their mayor, the "omes bonos fillosdalgo e foreros de Llanera" gathered in the town of Posada – the geographical center of the territory – to return to the obedience of Don Diego and his Church. The municipality appointed its representative, Juan Fernández, to solemnly declare on behalf of all of them, before the attending delegates of authority, their firm resolution and the promise not to rebel again in the future against their lords "in the said matters."

Once the municipal representative completed this task, the assembly of residents requested from the present episcopal delegate that they be absolved of the sentences of excommunication under which they fell, that the interdict weighing upon the entire territory be lifted, and that "any penalties, calumnies, sacrileges, and charges that had befallen them for the aforementioned reasons" be remitted.

In response to these requests, the provisor and general vicar of Don Diego, along with the procurators of the Dean and the chapter, displayed a generous conciliatory attitude toward the rebels, which manifested itself through a triple declaration of intent... they lifted the penalties they had incurred and ordered them, "as a sign of penitence," to choose thirty good men among them, twenty nobles and ten commoners, to attend a festive day at the Church of San Salvador in Oviedo/Uviéu, participating "in its procession barefoot, wearing sacks or doublets without any other covering, with ropes tied around them and candles in their hands." The provisor of the bishop solemnly pledged to absolve them from the penalties of excommunication and lift the interdict imposed on the municipality once this public penitential humiliation was fulfilled.

The festival takes place on the first weekend of July and has become the festival of Llanera and its residents, as it serves as a union and fraternal gathering for all the neighbors, just as their ancestors did.

The "Exconxuraos" are celebrated in the Llanera fairgrounds, where various activities and shows take place throughout the weekend, aiming to create an atmosphere that immerses the visitor in the medieval era. Different ribbons, banners, shields, warriors, jesters, knights, musicians, and more bring color to this medieval festival, which has become a reference not only at the regional level but also nationally.
Festival of Touristic Interest of the Principality of Asturias
Stuffed Onions Festival in L'Entregu/El Entrego, imagination at the table

The town of L'Entregu/El Entrego, in the municipality of San Martín del Rey Aurelio, is the world capital of stuffed onions, a brilliant culinary invention that originated from the creativity of a cook from this village, Aniceta Fueyo "la Nina," who came up with it in the 1940s to feed several priests during Lent.

So, coinciding with the feast of Saint Andrew, which falls on November 30th, L'Entregu/El Entrego celebrates the Stuffed Onions Festival in a grand manner. It should be mentioned that the festival lasts for several days, and the popularity of this dish is such that it transcends local, Asturian, and even Spanish borders.

Of course, the celebration includes a wide and varied cultural and leisure program: opening speech, musical performances, a culinary contest of "stuffed onions," and more.

It is true that the original dish consists of onions stuffed with tuna, but over time and with a desire to innovate, the recipe has expanded, and there are now stuffed onions with meat and even seafood. Ultimately, onions take center stage in a menu that also includes tripe stew and, for dessert, casadielles.

Stuffed Onions Festival is one of the most classic, unique, and lively gastronomic events in all of Asturias.
Fiesta of Our Lady of Guía
The Fiesta of Our Lady of Guía in Llanes, the privilege of antiquity

One of the most remarkable aspects of the Festival of Our Lady of Guía in Llanes is its maritime antiquity and tradition, evident from every angle.

The Hermitage of Guía is five hundred years old, and for just as long, there have been accounts of this profound devotion in the coastal town of Llanes. Another curious aspect is that its celebration coincides with that of Our Lady of Covadonga – the patron saint of Asturias – on September 8th. However, the Virgin of Guía does not diminish the importance of Cuadonga/Covadonga; on the contrary, it strengthens the sense of identity in Llanes and the eastern region of Asturias as a whole.

But the curiosities of this festival don't end there. One of the most visually stunning and colorful events is the nighttime procession held on September 7th. During this procession, the Virgin is carried from her hermitage to the Llanes Basilica, with a stop overlooking the sea, fireworks, and hundreds of women wearing Spanish mantillas. Some wear white mantillas while others wear black, each holding a candle and a white, fragrant flower known as "nardo" pinned to their lapels (this distinctive flower is the emblem of the Virgin of Guía). Walking in rows and accompanying the Virgin through the narrow streets of the historic center of Llanes, they create a unique scene unlike anything you would find in a ceremony of this kind.

The array of curiosities is completed by the Dance of Arches performed by children in the morning of September 8th in front of the Hermitage. The children execute the dance with special gracefulness, while adults dress in traditional Llanes attire, both male and female, and their numbers reach the hundreds.

Furthermore, for the past four decades, a vintage-style wooden train has arrived from Mieres, carrying hundreds of people who join in this celebration, where the jet-black attire of the Llanes costume shines brighter than the rays of the sun.
The Fiesta of the Virgen de Guía in Llanes
The Fiesta of the Virgen de Guía in Llanes
The Fiesta of the Virgen de Guía in Llanes
The Fiesta of the Virgen de Guía in Llanes
Harvest Festival of Quality Wine in Cangas
Tourist Interest Festival of the Principality of Asturias

The Harvest Festival is unique in Asturias, among other reasons because Cangas del Narcea is the only wine-producing region in the Principality, with a tradition dating back to the Middle Ages and with mountain vineyards that make this viticulture a truly heroic activity.

This festival takes place every year during the Pilar Bridge, in the first half of October, and there are multiple activities carried out around the grape harvest. In addition to the constant activity and atmosphere in the vineyards, the town of Cangas hosts a craft fair and market with all kinds of local products, as well as wine tastings, guided visits to the Wine Museum, gastronomy linked to the world of wine, etc. Numerous brotherhoods gather in Cangas del Narcea and have their own parade accompanied by the local Music Band.

It is four days of true devotion to the culture of Quality Wine from Cangas, where you can learn everything about this activity that has a thousand-year-old tradition in western Asturias, and that becomes more and more popular year after year.
L'Amuravela Festival in Cudillero, the 'pixueta' essence

This is one of the most curious and original fiestas of the whole of Asturias, having an important sea and "pixueto" flavour (the latter term referring to the language used yesteryear by the fishermen of Cudillero and exclusively in this town, with those living in this town of fishermen sometimes being called "pixuetos"). Taking all this into consideration, every 29th June, the festivity of San Pedro, Cudillero celebrates L'Amuravela.

The fiesta at the very least goes back to the 16th century and relates to the construction of the San Pedro parish church. It is original given that the fiesta starts with a person from Cudillero preaching, in verse and "pixueto" lingo, a sermon ironically summarising all that which took place during the year and begging for protection for the following year.

The verses of L'Amuravela contain historical references to the harbour, fishing, cosmopolite and seafaring characteristics of the town, together with social and religious pleads. This is a unique spectacle right in the amphitheatre of Cudillero, under full sail, in a colourful and fishing setting tastes of sea and tradition. And the fiesta commences to last several days with the blessing of San Pedro, the patron saint of Cudillero.

Ancient history, "pixueto" language and traditions and the hospitality of Cudillero all come together in the essence of L'Amuravela.
San Xuan/ San Juan de Beleño
The Guirria and Aguinaldo Festival: the first masquerade of the year in Asturias

The Guirria and Aguinaldo Festival takes place on January 1st  in San Xuan/ San Juan de Beleño, the capital of the district of Ponga. This celebration brings ancestral tradition and romanticism to New Year's Day. El Guirria, a mythological masked being – half trasgu (a mythological creature), half a carnival character – harasses women all day long: hugging them, embracing them and kissing them with total impunity. It is like a grand theatrical play by all the village, both indoors and outdoors.

Escorted by men on horseback, the Guirria is an almost invulnerable character for the year which is beginning. The role is normally played by a young man from the district - whose identity is kept secret -.  He kisses all the girls he finds on his way and beats and throws ashes on anyone who tries to stop him..

Meanwhile, the aguinalderos (gift seekers) ride around the houses on their shiny horses, like courtiers of the almost ghostly raid of the Guirria on the streets and houses of  San Xuan/ San Juan de Beleño. The townspeople generously provide these illustrious visitors with food and drink in their houses. So, with the joyful verses of the aguinalderos, the romantic lack of inhibition of the guirria and the complicity of the townspeople a new year full of joy begins.
Festival of Our Lady of Cébrano
Tourist Interest Festival of the Principality of Asturias
Our Lady of Cébrano in Teverga, at the foot of Peña Sobia

The Virgin of Cébrano is the patroness of Teverga, and for this reason, this sanctuary holds great devotional and historical significance. Every August 15th, this festival takes place in Carrea, attracting hundreds of people year after year, both locals and outsiders.

The sanctuary has a remarkable history, and its presbytery, in particular, is very ancient, dating back to the height of the pre-Romanesque art, around the 9th and 10th centuries. Furthermore, its location, at the foot of the magnificent Peña Sobia, is of unique beauty.

It is a typically Asturian festival, where the traditionally friendly and hospitable locals spare no expense, literally throwing caution to the wind, in the middle of August.
Interceltic Festival of Avilés and Region
Tourist Interest Festival of the Principality of Asturias.

The Interceltic Festival of Avilés and Region, one of the most important and representative festivals in Asturias, is a grand Celtic celebration. Every year, it welcomes folk and musical groups, as well as delegations from different countries where Celtic culture has deep roots and presence. Various events, showcasing craftsmanship, art, sports, and recreational activities, literally take over the city of Avilés and its surrounding area, highlighting the identity, uniqueness, and vibrancy of Celtic culture in this part of the Atlantic Arc.

Dozens of events, performances, theater shows, exhibitions, parades, gastronomic days featuring cider, traditional markets, and all kinds of displays related to Celtic culture, dominate these days of summer in Avilés and throughout Asturias.

The customs and traditions of the Celts are exposed like never before, for the delight and satisfaction of the thousands of people who participate in the festival throughout its duration.

The Celtic universe holds a special place in Avilés and its region.
Interceltic Festival of Avilés and Region
Tourist Interest Festival of the Principality of Asturias
Interceltic Festival of the West in Tapia de Casariego, with folk music by the seaside

The Interceltic Festival of the West, held in Tapia during the first half of August, is one of the musical highlights of the Asturian summer along the coast. In addition to the natural charm of the town of Tapia and its excellent summer atmosphere, this event adds a cultural and lively touch that makes it one of the major events in Asturias during this time.

An impressive lineup of folk music groups, both local and international, as well as bagpipe bands and other activities related to Celtic culture, fill the summer in Tapia with festivities and fun moments. All of this, with the added ingredient of a medieval market and a town fully engaged in its festival. And to top it off, the Cantabrian Sea provides its winds and foams to ensure everything runs smoothly.
Tourist Interest Festival of the Principality of Asturias.

One of the sweetest fiestas of the year falls on the second Sunday of May and takes place in Cabranes, more specifically in its capital Santolaya, coinciding with the fiestas of San Francisco de Paula.

Sunday is precisely the Grand Day of these fiestas and there is no better way to celebrate it than with the famous Rice Pudding Festival. There are many competitors in this competition, each with their singular knowledge and recipes for making the tastiest creamed rice in the world.

Simultaneous with the competition, a traditional market of handicrafts and farm food products. It is also possible to taste creamed rice free of charge all morning, as well as acquiring commemorative tubs of the festival.

The animation, the music, the atmosphere, the neighbourhood homages and the presence of the Confraternity of Rice are some of the components which season a perfect fiesta for "llambiones" (sweet toothed persons), in the incomparable, panoramic framework of Santolaya de Cabranes. In fact it is the ideal way to sweeten the springtime.
Festival of Touristic Interest of the Principality of Asturias
A fiesta which knows how to nourish

Each year, on August 1 in Candás, the capital of the la capital district of Carreño, the Sardina Festival is held. This veteran and populous festival was a pioneer of its type in Asturias and is framed within the famous fiestas of San Félix de Candás.

After almost four decades of celebrations – the first edition was in 1970 – it has become quite a classic and in an obligatory venue for lovers of fiestas and good gastronomy. On this day all the town of Candás is filled with the aroma and the taste of this succulent fish which is "worked on" with authentic masterfulness in Candás.

On each first of August, it is now a tradition to have grilled sardines which are prepared directly in the public eye in the stands in the Paseo de San Antonio. As a grand finale to such a brilliant and tasty day, the "golden sardine" is awarded to the restaurant which has prepared the fish best and with most inspiration.

At each edition of the festival thousands of kilos of sardines are consumed. One practical piece of advice is to drink, best of all some small glasses of cider. And for those who wish and are in the mood, enjoy the atmosphere and the fun until the early hours of the morning.
Tourist Interest Festival of the Principality of Asturias
The Apple Festival of Villaviciosa, a way to discover this fruit with infinite possibilities

The Apple Festival of Villaviciosa is a true tribute to this tasty and legendary fruit, and a magnificent showcase of all activities directly related to this genuinely Asturian product, which is abundantly produced in the Villaviciosa area.

Villaviciosa fully embraces its festival, which is usually held in October, with a wide range of entertaining activities such as gastronomic events, contests, music, autumn market, machinery market, theater, exhibitions, workshops, live cooking, tastings, children's activities, tourist train, and more.

Among the countless activities for all ages and tastes, the apple exhibitions and tastings stand out, as they are not very common. Various workshops also bring the general public closer to the vast universe surrounding apples and cider.

All of this takes place in the privileged setting of the illustrious town of Villaviciosa, with its interesting historical center, abundant cultural and commercial attractions, and a vibrant atmosphere.
Tourist Interest Festival of the Principality of Asturias
Hazelnut Festival or the dedication to a precious forest fruit

The Hazelnut Festival is celebrated every year on the first Sunday of October in the capital of the Piloña council, L'Infiestu. This great tribute to one of Asturias' quintessential native fruits finds the best stage to showcase itself in the lands of Piloña.

Piloña has a strong natural tradition linked to forests, craftsmanship, wood, organic agriculture, rural tourism, and more. For this reason, the Hazelnut Festival is a recreational and cultural event deeply rooted in this territory. It features a program of festive activities such as traditional markets, craft and agri-food product exhibitions, bird exhibitions, woodcraft exhibitions, bowling championships, and more. All of this culminates in typical open-air dances and celebrations.

This festival highlights the respect for traditions and the celebration of Asturias' natural products.
Festival de Pipe Bands of Villa de Candás
Festival of touristic interest in the Principality of Asturias

The Pipe Band Festival of Candás has been growing and consolidating for two decades as one of the grand musical venues of the summer in Asturias on the central coast of the region.

The Villa de Candás has known how to perfectly agglutinate the rise of popular and traditional Asturian culture, and this festival is a clear fun and cultural exponent of the historical time we are living.

Bands from several places fill and animate the streets of Candás filling them with culture, music and fun, in an atmosphere which exudes the quintessence of Asturias.
Festival de Pipe Bands of Villa de Candás
Festival de Pipe Bands of Villa de Candás
Festival de Pipe Bands of Villa de Candás
Festival de Pipe Bands of Villa de Candás
Festival of Touristic Interest in Asturias
Salmon Fair in Corniana/Cornellana, a true tribute to the king of the rive

The Salmon Fair is an ideal occasion to get to know Corniana/Cornellana and all the beauties of its surroundings, both in terms of nature and culture. The month of April, when the fishing season opens, is the perfect time for this unique event, dedicated exclusively to salmon and its habitat.

Moreover, the fair features the excitement of the Campanu de Asturias auction (the first salmon of the season), which becomes a social, sporting, and cultural event in this land.

The life of the salmon and its environment are the central focus of a fair where outdoor activities, mainly fishing and hunting, as well as other adventure tourism activities, are a real attraction for locals and visitors alike.

Parallel to the fair, activities related to the attractions of Cornellana and the Narcea River are scheduled, such as a guided salmon route or visits to the impressive Monastery of San Salvador de Cornellana, one of the most significant landmarks on the Camino de Santiago.
Fair of Ascension Day in Oviedo/Uviéu, a grand Asturian festival

The Fair of Ascension Day in Oviedo/Uviéu, is now a classical venue among livestock fairs and is one of the most important competitions in Asturias.

In the middle of spring, the capital of Asturias displays all its attractions and a grand Asturian market is put in place in the square of the Cathedral for the fair. It has the traditional Asturian atmosphere, in a strategic location with the grand historical value and marvellous beauty of the heart of the historical quarter of the city.

Parallel to the livestock fair and the Asturian market, the area of the Paseo de la Losa has an extensive interactive space with exhibitions, musical performances and other cultural activities, which attract thousands and thousands of people.

All of these activities give added value to the atmosphere of the capital and its surroundings.
The Virgin del Carmen of Torazo in Cabranes
Festival of touristic interest in the Principality of Asturias
Or the most crowded parade of branches

On the last Sunday of August, Torazu dresses up in its finery in order to celebrate the feast of the Virgin del Carmen. This town in the district of Cabranes, well known for having been the Exemplary Town of Asturias in 2008, and for joining in perfect harmony the traditional architecture Indiana or American architecture due to the emigration of many of its inhabitants to America, it is really a welcoming and colourful place, where the festivity of the Virgin del Carmen is celebrated in a big way and at the wrong time, but it has been this way for several centuries.

Although the Virgin del Carmen is on July 16, in Torazo it is celebrated one and a half months late, and tradition tells that this change of date was perhaps owing to the fact that the spelt had to be harvested in order to be able to make the bread which is traditionally offered to the Virgin as a sign of gratitude.

On Sunday, the celebrations begin early with a street procession and the moment most expected and spectacular, which is also a centenarian tradition, is the parade of branches, with the neighbours of the districts wearing regional costumes as the main players. This parade is one of the most crowded and colourful in all Asturias, and is undoubtedly the distinctive part of the Carmen de Torazo, whose fiesta is crowned with a first class verbena (open air dance).

Festival of Touristic Interest of the Principality of Asturias
The carriages of Valdesoto: a celebration of Asturian rural tradition

The Carriages of Valdesoto, which originated as a festival in the second half of the 20th century, traditionally mark the grand finale of the San Félix patron saint festivities. They are one of the most significant events that exalt the customs and rural traditions of yesteryear in Asturias.

Numerous local groups, representing various neighborhoods in Valdesoto, diligently prepare their best carriages for the parade that fills the streets of the village. A noteworthy feature is that the carriages of Valdesoto have a strong theatrical element, with occasional actors performing scenes related to the theme depicted by each carriage. Many of these scenes draw inspiration from Asturian rural traditions, allowing the audience to learn about customs, tools, and an entire culture that is gradually disappearing with the passage of time and social changes.

The festivities culminate with a hearty Asturian-style meal served in the festival meadow, followed by the jury's announcement of the best carriages and a fireworks display.
Official International Show Jumping Competition of Spain / CSIO
Tourist Interest Festival of the Principality of Asturias

The Gijón Equestrian Championship is a sports competition of show jumping that, over its 76-year history, has evolved to become one of the most prominent events internationally in this sport discipline.

The Gijón Championship is not just another competition. It is meticulously planned down to the smallest details, from the aesthetics of the obstacles to the quality of the facilities, organization, and sports participation. Additionally, it offers a diverse range of cultural and recreational activities that run parallel to the event.

Cultural, educational, commercial, children's activities, discussions, gastronomy, and exhibitions form a universe of leisure linked to equestrianism, making this competition a unique sporting and social event in Spain.

Due to its great appeal, this competition has a deep social connection in the city of Gijón/Xixón, as well as beyond. Thousands of people attend this event every year and enthusiastically follow the sporting events, while also witnessing the presence of numerous personalities and celebrities from various fields who come to experience this exciting event firsthand.

It is a unique opportunity to explore and enjoy Gijón/Xixón and its surroundings, with its splendid rural and coastal areas, offering leisure activities such as walks, beaches, golf courses, and more. Moreover, it takes place during the last fortnight of August, making it an excellent time to visit.

Touristic Festival of Interest of the Principality of Asturias
Casín Cheese Contest in Caso, an ancient flavor in an idyllic setting

Casín Cheese is one of the oldest known cheeses. It is an exquisite and elaborated artisan product made from raw cow's milk, which has a Protected Designation of Origin (PDO).

The local community of the municipality of Caso - especially its women - has managed to keep this ancestral tradition alive, despite the hardships that the countryside has experienced throughout history.

Since time immemorial, the coexistence between the people of Caso and the cattle has resulted in a symbiosis that goes beyond mere economic exploitation, with Casín Cheese being the delicious testament to that unique relationship.

For this reason, the Casín Cheese Contest has been held annually for several decades, usually taking place on the last Saturday of August.

The event revolves around two fundamental aspects: the market with stalls of Casín Cheese producers and the cheese competition among dairies affiliated with the Casín Cheese PDO. Parallel to these activities, various complementary events take place, such as cooking contests, tastings, workshops, exhibitions, performances by folk groups, charity marathons, and special menus.

Furthermore, this contest provides an excellent opportunity to get to know the Redes Natural Park better. Its landscapes, routes, museums, people, and the lively festive atmosphere of this unique area of Asturias.
Festival of Touristic Interest of the Principality of Asturias
Gamonedo Cheese Contest in Onís, with all the flavor of the Picos de Europa

The Gamonedo or Gamonéu cheese is one of the most characteristic and appreciated cheeses that have been produced since time immemorial in the Picos de Europa region. Closely linked to the town of the same name, this cheese is a true gem for cheese lovers and a highly valued product for culinary use.

At the end of October, the Gamonedo Cheese Contest takes place in Benia, the capital of the municipality of Onís, in a festive event that lasts the entire weekend. It is a true celebration of the local culture, not only for the cheese but also because there are various contests and exhibitions of the Asturian Pita chicken and the oveya xalda sheep. In addition, there is a championship of traditional bowling, music, and many other activities that create a lively atmosphere in Benia during those dates
The Cabrales Cheese Competition, the tastiest fiesta

On the last Sunday of August every year, Arenas de Cabrales is decorated in order to celebrate the competition organised for one of the most well-known and famous cheeses in the world: Cabrales.

On this day the people of Arenas roll out the red carpet and both the people of Arenas and elsewhere strive to get to know all the cheeses competing and to enjoy the Asturian fiesta atmosphere which begins early in the morning. The day is long and tasty with the participation of pipe bands and folkloric groups. During the week, several cultural and gastronomic acts linked to cheese and its and its environment, which include tasting, visits to museums and caves, exhibitions, presentations, a traditional market, ethnographic routes, bowling matches, a folklore festival, exhibition of village women's costumes, etc. In short, this is homage to the culture of cheese, and the social and natural environment in which it is made. In fact, it is much more than a gastronomic fiesta. Undoubtedly it is one of the obligatory venues of the Asturian summertime.
Tourist Interest Festival of the Principality of Asturias

Santa Marina Beach in Ribadesella/Ribeseya becomes a natural racecourse of immense appeal every year for the thousands of fans and tourists who come there to experience and enjoy the strength and beauty of the Horse Races, which take place during Easter week.

The surroundings of this urban beach in Ribadesella/Ribeseya are truly spectacular. A set of Indian architecture buildings, representative of a whole era in Asturian history, line the promenade. Furthermore, the chapel of the Virgen de Guía to the east, and the cliffs of Punta'l Pozu on the other side - with their dinosaur footprints - complete a very striking landscape. And it is in this setting that the Horse Races add their touch of plasticity and sport.

Precisely, this sporting event combines excitement, a great atmosphere, and a landscape of great beauty, while also providing an approach to the world of horse racing. Therefore, all these reasons make this event a different and interesting leisure option in the incomparable setting of the coastal town of Ribadesella/Ribeseya.
Gold panning championship in Navelgas when all that glitters is gold
Golden batting championship at Navelgas, when all that glitters is gold

Navelgas is a typical town in western Asturias, in the district of Tineo, well known worldwide as being a European reference for gold panning. The tradition of gold in the zone goes back to Roman times when this empire exploited the gold deposits in the Asturian subsoil.


From that time until now, many centuries have passed but the gold tradition continues in Navelgas, which has a Gold Museum.


This year the National Gold Panning Championship will be held on July 29, 30 and 31, and substantial participation is expected, as well a turnout of spectators. It will be enlivened with parades, procession, pipers and, of course, excellent gastronomy and an atmosphere of wonderful hospitality.
Festivals and Activities of Touristic Interest in the Principality of Asturias

The Indianos Fair is celebrated every year in the month of July in Colombres, the capital of the municipality of Ribadedeva. This festival began in 2008 with the aim of paying tribute to the Hispanic-American culture that exists in this region, thanks to the significant migratory flows that took place in the 19th and 20th centuries from this part of eastern Asturias to the American continent.

The event combines various cultural, gastronomic, and recreational activities throughout the weekend, all of which are related to the Indiano theme. It is a total immersion in this culture, which over time has generated numerous expressions related to architecture, clothing, lifestyle, gastronomy, folklore, music, art, craftsmanship, literature, and more.

Colombres, the capital of Ribadedeva and also designated as an Exemplary Village of Asturias in 2015, provides an ideal setting for the celebration of this event due to its rich Indiano tradition, evident in its splendid architecture, history, and ambiance.

The Indianos Fair in Colombres has solidified its position year after year, expanding its diverse and enjoyable program of activities, making it an unmissable event of the summer in eastern Asturias.
Day of Asturias in Gijón/Xixón, a display of "Asturianness"

The Day of Asturias in Gijón/Xixón is a summer classic in this city and is always held on the first Sunday of August. After a countryside picnic in Cerro de Santa Catalina, there is a parade of carriages and folkloric Asturian groups and of groups from other regions and countries along the Paseo del Muro de San Lorenzo up to El Molinón Stadium, where it finishes off with a great festival.

This fiesta is the prelude to the Great Week in Gijon/Xixón starting a few days later, a perfect example of the traditional hospitality of the city towards people and groups coming from all around the world to participate and give their touch of colour and exoticism in this festival.

The Cerro de Santa Catalina, the gardens of El Náutico, the Plaza Mayor, the Muro de San Lorenzo and El Molinón Stadium are typical scenarios of Gijón/Xixón , all along the coastal part of the city, leading the fiesta to have exceptionally beautiful views, apart from the leisure component.
America Day in Asturias in Oviedo
America Day in Asturias in Oviedo/Uviéu, bringing continents together

The Asturian capital, Oviedo/Uviéu, has always had the vocation of being cosmopolite, solidary and a connection between cultures, a vocation to culture, the fiesta and social and human relationships. That said, the America Day in Asturias is a clear example of all this coming together in a single and unforgettable day.

The America Day in Asturias was held for the first time in 1950 and, since then, the date chosen for this is 19th September every year, within the setting of the Fiestas de San Mateo. It is a folkloric and carriage parade, with the prominence of both the Asturian culture and that of those Latin American countries to which Asturians have traditionally emigrated, even making reference to European countries which have welcomed groups of Asturians.

Certain figures in the parade, such as Telva and Pinón, are a heartfelt tribute to the founder of the parade, the brilliant artist Alfonso Iglesias, who raised Asturian culture to present art through his graphic and intelligent humour rooted in the Asturian identity.

A true coming together of cultures, original and extremely enjoyable.
The floral carpets of Corpus Christi
Fiesta of touristic interest in the Principality of Asturias
Colourfulness invades the streets of the town

"Colours were made for tastes and for colours flowers". This popular saying becomes reality at the Corpus Christi weekend in Castropol, which is adorned on Sunday with its famous and traditional floral carpets.

So one of the most beautiful seafaring towns in Asturias reaches the zenith of its colourfulness and customs as always with the staging of its floral carpets for the religious festival of Corpus Christi. Not even the oldest inhabitants remember how or when this curious custom began. The only thing that is known for certain is that always at this same epoch the narrow, sinuous streets of its haughty, panoramic old quarter have been adorned by these elaborate, colourful vegetable coverings which leave the inhabitants and visitors open mouthed year after year.

The grand day of the fiesta, Corpus Christi, all the First Communion children carry the Baby Jesus and the Virgin Mary on their shoulders, followed by the band of Castropol and numerous members of the public who gather for the celebration, fascinated by this special moment.

This year, 2016, Corpus Christi Sunday is on May 29.
